mentions.context: Crop2ML model components can be validated by executing unit tests.
Crop2ML is a framework for crop model component development, exchange, and reuse between PBM platforms.
Crop2ML follows and extends these principals.
Crop2ML provides a level of abstraction that enables a shared representation of model components between PBM platforms.
Crop2ML framework provides a source-to-source transformation system (CyMLT) which converts
Crop2ML provides a logical, standardized but flexible support to facilitate model sharing between modeling platforms through the definition of a directory structure (Fig. 8).
Crop2ML is in line with MDE.
Crop2ML is based on a transformation process through a set of refinement of models and code with some extensible rules defined as templates in Python.
Crop2ML produces code in a target language but also adapts the code to fit with PBM platform specificities.

Crop2ML has some limitations, which can be addressed in the next versions, either by extending the model specifications with shared concepts or by adapting the target PBM platforms to Crop2ML specification and language.
Crop2ML proposes an open framework to manage all the steps of model lifecycle.
Crop2ML can be used to import and export model components into many different crop simulation platforms.
CyMLT implementation relies on the transformation of the abstract syntax tree (AST) generated from the syntax analysis of the CyML code.
CyMLT proposes a unique approach to transform the Abstract Semantic Graph into readable source code in many different languages.
DSSAT submodules contain specific platform variables such as control variables that need to be removed to produce CyML model algorithms.

For instance, DSSAT defines a subroutine with all the variables as argument, Record defines a class method (compute) with the variables as attributes of the class and uses specific operator "()" to manage temporal variables, while BioMA defines a class method (CalculateModel) that takes as argument data structures implementing each category of variables (state, rate, auxiliary, exogenous).

This reuse approach is supported by the Agricultural Modeling Exchange Initiative (AMEI), which brings together some of the most widely used crop modelling and simulation platforms, including the Agricultural Production Systems sIMulator (APSIM, Holzworth et al., 2018), the Biophysical Model Applications (BioMA; Donatelli et al., 2010), the Decision Support System for Agrotechnology Transfer (DSSAT; Jones et al., 2003;Hoogenboom et al., 2019), OpenAlea (Pradal et al., 2015), the REnovation and COORDination of agroecosystems modelling (RECORD; Bergez et al., 2013), and the Scientific Impact assessment and Modeling Platform for Advanced Crop and Ecosystem management (Simplace; Gaiser et al., 2013) and other crop models such as STICS (Brisson et al., 2010) or SiriusQuality (Martre et al., 2006).
